title: Epilepsy - Chronic Management
scope: ** Long-term outpatient management of adults with established epilepsy diagnosis on stable antiseizure medication (ASM) regimens. Covers routine monitoring, ASM optimization, comorbidity management (depression, anxiety, bone health), women's health and pregnancy planning, driving and employment considerations, ASM withdrawal in seizure-free patients, and bone health. Excludes initial seizure workup (see New Onset Seizure), acute breakthrough seizures (see Breakthrough Seizure), drug-resistant epilepsy requiring surgical evaluation (see Drug-Resistant Epilepsy), and status epilepticus (see SE template).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Routine monitoring of adherence and therapeutic dosing; obtain trough level (before morning dose); establish individual therapeutic level when seizure-free
Essential/Core Labs.target: Within therapeutic range; document individual target level when well controlled

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Annual monitoring for ASM hematologic effects; carbamazepine (leukopenia, aplastic anemia rare); valproate (thrombocytopenia); felbamate (aplastic anemia)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; WBC <3500 or platelets <100K → evaluate ASM cause

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Annual monitoring of hepatic function (ASM metabolism, hepatotoxicity); renal function (ASM dosing); electrolytes (hyponatremia with carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hyponatremia → ASM-related SIADH; elevated LFTs → evaluate hepatotoxicity

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Annual screening for ALL epilepsy patients; enzyme-inducing ASMs (phenytoin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital) and valproate accelerate vitamin D metabolism → osteoporosis and fractures
Phenytoin and carbamazepine deplete folate; B12 screening in elderly; folate critical for women of childbearing potential (neural tube defect prevention)
Enzyme-inducing ASMs increase total cholesterol and LDL; cardiovascular risk monitoring
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; elevated → statin if indicated; consider switching to non-enzyme-inducing ASM

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Annual thyroid screening; valproate and carbamazepine can affect thyroid function; hypothyroidism increases seizure threshold (protective) but may cause fatigue
For protein-bound drugs (phenytoin, valproate) in pregnancy, hypoalbuminemia, renal failure, elderly
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Free phenytoin 1-2 mcg/mL; free valproate 5-15 mcg/mL

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Annual or PRN for patients on valproate; encephalopathy can occur with normal LFTs; also check if new confusion/lethargy

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Baseline for patients on enzyme-inducing ASMs >2 years; all patients >50; seizure-related falls increase fracture risk

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology follow-up every 3-6 months for seizure-free patients; every 1-3 months during ASM changes or if not well controlled
Comprehensive epilepsy center referral if seizures persist despite two or more appropriately chosen ASMs (meets ILAE definition of drug-resistant epilepsy)
Psychiatry referral for depression or anxiety screening positive (PHQ-9 ≥10 or GAD-7 ≥10); psychiatric comorbidities affect seizure control and quality of life
Reproductive endocrinology or OB/GYN referral for preconception counseling in women of childbearing potential; ASM teratogenicity review and optimization before pregnancy
Neuropsychological testing referral for cognitive complaints potentially related to ASMs; baseline assessment before surgery evaluation or ASM changes
Endocrinology referral for metabolic bone disease (osteoporosis on DEXA); PCOS in women on valproate; testosterone deficiency in men on enzyme-inducing ASMs
Social work for disability documentation, vocational rehabilitation, insurance assistance, and community support services
Driving evaluation by state DMV and neurology documentation of seizure-free interval per state requirements; commercial driving restrictions per federal DOT regulations
Ophthalmology referral for patients on vigabatrin (visual field testing q3 months) or any patient with visual complaints

Patient Instructions.item: Take ASMs at the same time every day; use pill organizers and phone alarms; missing even one dose increases seizure risk — contact neurologist if unable to afford or obtain medications
Maintain consistent sleep schedule with 7-9 hours nightly; sleep deprivation is the strongest modifiable seizure trigger; avoid shift work if possible
Do not stop ASMs abruptly; sudden discontinuation can trigger status epilepticus even in well-controlled patients — always taper under neurologist guidance
Return to ED immediately if seizure lasts >5 minutes, multiple seizures without recovery, seizure in water, significant injury during seizure, or first seizure in pregnancy
Do not drive until seizure-free for state-mandated period (typically 3-12 months); report seizures to neurologist for driving documentation; commercial driving has stricter federal requirements

Women of childbearing potential: use reliable contraception (IUD preferred over oral contraceptives if on enzyme-inducing ASMs); notify neurologist BEFORE planning pregnancy for medication optimization
Inform all prescribing doctors and pharmacists about epilepsy and ASMs before starting new medications; many drugs interact with ASMs (antibiotics, antidepressants, pain medications)
Avoid excessive alcohol (alcohol withdrawal and binge drinking lower seizure threshold); if consuming alcohol, limit to 1 drink maximum with food
Carry medical alert identification (bracelet or app) with epilepsy diagnosis and medications listed

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (30 minutes, 5 days/week) improves seizure control, mood, and cardiovascular health; no restriction on exercise type unless frequent tonic/drop seizures (avoid swimming alone, climbing)
Stress reduction through regular exercise, mindfulness, cognitive behavioral therapy; chronic stress is an independent seizure trigger
Weight management: topiramate and zonisamide may help with weight loss; valproate and pregabalin may cause weight gain — consider when selecting ASMs
Bone health: weight-bearing exercise, calcium and vitamin D supplementation, DEXA screening, and bisphosphonate if osteoporotic — especially critical for patients on enzyme-inducing ASMs
Home safety: shower instead of baths, avoid locked bathroom doors, use stove guards, microwave preferred over stovetop, carpeted floors reduce injury risk during falls
SUDEP awareness: discuss SUDEP risk openly; optimizing seizure control is the best prevention; nocturnal supervision and seizure detection devices reduce risk

differential.features: Waxing/waning; eyes closed; pelvic thrusting; asynchronous limb movements; duration >2 min; lack of postictal confusion; may coexist with epilepsy
differential.tests: Video-EEG monitoring; postictal prolactin (normal in PNES)

differential.features: Triggered by standing, heat, emotion; brief convulsive movements possible (convulsive syncope); rapid recovery
Sudden LOC without warning; palpitations; family history of sudden cardiac death
differential.tests: ECG; Holter; event monitor; cardiac MRI

differential.features: Episodes during sleep; cataplexy; sleep paralysis; REM behavior disorder
Anxiety; hyperventilation; palpitations; derealization; preserved consciousness; gradual onset
Focal neurologic deficit; vascular risk factors; abrupt onset; negative symptoms (weakness, numbness) vs positive (seizure movements)
Visual aura (positive phenomena spreading over minutes); headache follows; duration 5-60 min

evidence.recommendation: Lamotrigine and levetiracetam first-line for focal epilepsy; valproate first-line for generalized
Valproate should be avoided in women of childbearing potential due to teratogenicity and neurodevelopmental effects
ASM withdrawal after 2+ seizure-free years: ~35% recurrence risk; abnormal EEG and known etiology increase risk
Depression and anxiety highly prevalent in epilepsy; SSRIs safe and do not worsen seizures
SUDEP risk reduction: optimize seizure control, nocturnal supervision, avoid prone sleeping
Enzyme-inducing ASMs reduce bone mineral density; screening and supplementation recommended
Enzyme-inducing ASMs reduce oral contraceptive efficacy; IUDs recommended
Lamotrigine levels decrease 50-70% during pregnancy; monthly monitoring recommended
Refer drug-resistant epilepsy for surgical evaluation; surgery superior to continued medical therapy for mesial TLE
Seizure diary improves seizure reporting accuracy and patient engagement
